G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and has exercised control over the common areas, entry doors, and security conditions of the building at 45 Washington Avenue, Chelsea, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and has exercised control over the common areas, entry doors, and security conditions of the building at 45 Washington Avenue, Chelsea, Massachusetts.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff a statutory and common-law duty to maintain the building and common areas in a reasonably safe and secure condition and to ensure that Plaintiffs quiet enjoyment of the Premises was not interfered with, as required by G.L. c. 186,  and applicable case law, including but not limited to *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); and *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case squarely addresses a landlord’s statutory duty under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the quiet enjoyment statute) and recognizes that a landlord may be liable where its omissions allow conditions in common areas that seriously interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment of their premises. The SJC holds that if the housing authority fails to take reasonable measures within its control to address unlawful activity in common areas, that failure can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and it remands for fact-finding on that issue. While the opinion does not frame this as a generalized negligence “security” duty, it clearly supports the proposition that a landlord has a statutory (and closely related common-law) obligation to maintain common areas in a condition that does not seriously interfere with tenants’ quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff a statutory and common-law duty to maintain the building and common areas in a reasonably safe and secure condition and to ensure that Plaintiffs quiet enjoyment of the Premises was not interfered with, as required by G.L. c. 186,  and applicable case law, including but not limited to *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); and *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case squarely concerns the landlord’s implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that a landlord can be liable where conditions substantially interfere with a tenant’s enjoyment and are within the landlord’s control, even if the landlord did not intend the interference. The court emphasized the landlord’s obligation not to permit activities (here, a lounge’s noise) that deprive tenants of reasonably habitable, quiet premises and allowed tenants to withhold rent on that basis. This directly supports the cited proposition that a landlord has a common-law duty to ensure tenants’ quiet enjoyment and to maintain premises free from such interferences.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff a statutory and common-law duty to maintain the building and common areas in a reasonably safe and secure condition and to ensure that Plaintiffs quiet enjoyment of the Premises was not interfered with, as required by G.L. c. 186,  and applicable case law, including but not limited to *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); and *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: Berman & Sons addresses the landlord’s implied warranty of habitability and the tenant’s right to rent abatement when the landlord fails to provide adequate heat and hot water, even without fault. It does not discuss a general duty to maintain the building and common areas in a reasonably safe and secure condition or to ensure quiet enjoyment, nor does it interpret G.L. c. 186. The opinion is about contractual/warranty obligations and rent abatement, not about the broader statutory and common-law duties described in the proposition.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition.” Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 198 (1973), quoted in Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. at 199.

G.L. c. 111, \u0002\u00a7\u00a7 127A\u00.proposition: The condition of the main entry door and lock constitutes a defective and unsafe condition within the meaning of G.L. c. 186,  and violates the implied warranty of habitability and minimum standards of fitness, habitability, and safety under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A, the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.), and related case law, including *Hemingway v. Fernandez*, 363 Mass. 46 (1973), and *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: The condition of the main entry door and lock constitutes a defective and unsafe condition within the meaning of G.L. c. 186,  and violates the implied warranty of habitability and minimum standards of fitness, habitability, and safety under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A, the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.), and related case law, including *Hemingway v. Fernandez*, 363 Mass. 46 (1973), and *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).

Hemingway v. Fernandez, 363 Mass. 46 (19.proposition: The condition of the main entry door and lock constitutes a defective and unsafe condition within the meaning of G.L. c. 186,  and violates the implied warranty of habitability and minimum standards of fitness, habitability, and safety under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A, the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.), and related case law, including *Hemingway v. Fernandez*, 363 Mass. 46 (1973), and *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Hemingway v. Fernandez, 363 Mass. 46 (19.support_reasoning: This opinion is a mechanics’ lien/bond case under G.L. c. 149, § 29 concerning whether a subcontractor’s sworn statement of claim was timely and properly filed with an appropriate “officer or agent” of a regional school district. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, G.L. c. 186, implied warranty of habitability, G.L. c. 111 or the State Sanitary Code, nor does it address conditions of entry doors or locks. The citation to this case for the stated habitability proposition is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
Hemingway v. Fernandez, 363 Mass. 46 (19.relevant_excerpt: “It is agreed that the sole issue is whether LaBonte’s sworn statement of claim was filed with the proper person within ninety days of the last date when LaBonte furnished equipment for the project… If Dr. Trainor is properly described as a ‘contracting officer or agent’ of the district then LaBonte’s claim was seasonably filed. In the circumstances of this case, we believe that Dr. Trainor is properly described as an ‘agent’ of the district and thus was a proper person to receive the notice of claim.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The condition of the main entry door and lock constitutes a defective and unsafe condition within the meaning of G.L. c. 186,  and violates the implied warranty of habitability and minimum standards of fitness, habitability, and safety under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A, the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.), and related case law, including *Hemingway v. Fernandez*, 363 Mass. 46 (1973), and *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This portion of Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway (the Quirico concurrence/dissent) discusses, at a high level, the landlord’s obligations under the State Sanitary Code and the concept of an implied warranty of habitability tied to statutory minimum standards, but it does not address, factually or doctrinally, any issue about a defective main entry door or lock. The opinion remains at the level of general doctrine and statutory framework and never identifies exterior doors/locks as constituting a defective or unsafe condition under G.L. c. 186 or the Sanitary Code. Thus, it does not provide specific authority for the precise proposition that the condition of the main entry door and lock, in particular, violates the implied warranty of habitability or those statutes and regulations.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code…[which] fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units… As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would…hold…that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards…”

105 CMR 410.351, 410.480.proposition: The unsafe and unsecured condition of the main entry door also constitutes a violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code’s requirement that the owner maintain the building and its means of egress in good repair and in a safe condition, and provide reasonable security, including functioning locks on building entry doors, see 105 CMR 410.351, 410.480, and cases such as *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979), and *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: The unsafe and unsecured condition of the main entry door also constitutes a violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code’s requirement that the owner maintain the building and its means of egress in good repair and in a safe condition, and provide reasonable security, including functioning locks on building entry doors, see 105 CMR 410.351, 410.480, and cases such as *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979), and *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions “inadequate door locks” only as one of several State Sanitary Code violations underlying a general breach of warranty of habitability, but it does not analyze 105 CMR 410.351 or 410.480, does not discuss the owner’s duty to maintain means of egress or provide reasonable security, and does not articulate any legal rule about functioning locks on building entry doors. The case is about utilities, security deposits, rent control, habitability damages, and c. 93A, not about egress or security obligations under the code. Thus it does not substantively support the specific proposition stated.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Plaintiffs reasonable expectation of a secure and habitable residence with functional locks and basic building security is an essential element of quiet enjoyment protected by G.L. c. 186,  and by common law. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion defines the standard of landlord fault required for a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that at least negligence with notice is required; it does not discuss or frame the tenant’s interest as a “reasonable expectation of a secure and habitable residence with functional locks and basic building security.” The case concerns lead paint and the relationship between the lead paint statute and the quiet enjoyment statute, not building security or locks. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated, even though it discusses the scope of quiet enjoyment generally.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear…there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Plaintiffs reasonable expectation of a secure and habitable residence with functional locks and basic building security is an essential element of quiet enjoyment protected by G.L. c. 186,  and by common law. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that G.L. c. 186, § 14 protects a tenant’s quiet enjoyment against serious interferences and that the statute covers at least reckless failures to maintain safe and sanitary conditions, including repeated flooding. However, the opinion does not frame the right in terms of an “expectation of a secure and habitable residence with functional locks and basic building security,” nor does it discuss locks or building security at all. Simon v. Solomon is authority for quiet enjoyment protection against unsanitary, uninhabitable flooding conditions, not specifically for security/locks as an essential element of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Award Plaintiff the costs of this action, including filing fees and other allowable costs pursuant to G.L. c. 186,  and G.L. c. 261, and, to the extent she may become represented, reasonable attorneys fees as permitted by G.L. c. 186, .
